results.title: Watch out for my plant
results.brief_description: A young inner-city boy struggles to grow a plant in a tiny patch of dirt. We see his determination, a special relationship with an older man and the flowering and destruction of the plant. Shows that everyone can do something about his environment, given initiative, responsibility and perseverance. Suitable for middle and upper primary levels.

results.title: Walking the mob
results.creator_credit: Lionel Hudson, Keith Fraser and ABC-TV (Australia)
results.brief_description: The life and work of the cattle drovers shown as they take a big herd across central Australia. The drover’s way of lie in the outback Australia. A typical drover, Jack Jones, and his team bring a mob of 600 cattle from Bergmont Station in the Northern Territory to Longreach, Queensland. Their route follows the Thompson River, one of the country’s driest regions. Shows new and old methods of transporting cattle; one lot being walked and the other lot by train.

results.title: Waistlines and lifelines
results.creator_credit: Russell Gibbs, John Banks and Advent Films
results.brief_description: Ron has a weight problem. He tries massage and the crash diet, but to no avail. A heart attack scare sends him to his doctor, who recommends graded exercises and consultation with a dietician.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Russell Gibbs, John Banks and Advent Films

results.title: The Use of measuring instruments: the volumetric flask
results.creator_credit: L.M. Simmons, Craig Baynes and Australian Teaching Films
results.brief_description: The standard method of using a volumetric flask; warning against placing hot liquid in a flask; pouring liquid into the flask; using a pipette to add liquid; storing liquid in a reagent bottle.

results.title: Voices of Malaya
results.creator_credit: Ralth Eaton, Terry Trench, Central Office of Information and Colonial Office
results.brief_description: Voices of Malaya was made before hostilities in Malaya began, in the period immediately after World War 2. It is primarily a background study of the problems facing a country with a population of five million people - Malayan, Chinese-Malayan, Indian-Malayan and European - who are suffering from the aftermath of war. It shows the efforts of the mixed nationalities of Malaya working and living together in the best interests of their country. Music by Elizabeth Lutyens, played by The Philharmonic Orchestra and conducted by John Hollingsworth.

results.title: Violent youth: the un-met challenge
results.brief_description: Through interviews with various people, including youths in a New York Training Centre, the film tries to explain the reasons for young people getting into trouble and the possible remedies. As there is no success as yet, all possibilities for treatment are worth looking at.
results.description: Through interviews with various people, including youths in a New York Training Centre, the film tries to explain the reasons for young people getting into trouble and the possible remedies. As there is no success as yet, all possibilities for treatment are worth looking at.

results.title: The Village that vanished beneath the Nile
results.creator_credit: Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations
results.brief_description: The building of the Aswan Dam on the Nile necessitated the resettlement of the 45,000 people of Wadi Halfa - a town on the border of Egypt and the Sudan. Shows traditional Arab life along the river, and the movement of the people 800 miles south.

results.title: A Village school
results.creator_credit: Colonial Film Unit and Great Britain. Ministry of Information
results.brief_description: A study of the school at Ashley Green, in Buckinghamshire, England during World War II, when it was greatly enlarged to cater for children evacuated from London and other big cities.

results.title: News digest [No. 14]
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “News digest”.
Magazine items: 14-day commando course in cliff-climbing and descents for a C.M.F. company; “Frostbite regatta” - hardy all year yachtsmen race in eight-foot sabots on Waranga Reservoir in Northern Victoria; “Four in one” - a Carlton Methodist church where the service may be followed in Spanish, Italian, Hungarian and English, thus assisting migrants’ integration; “Whirlybird weapon” - helicopters used to spray crops in the Mallee prove their reliability; “Bouncing Babies” - veteran cars prove their reliability during a lively car trial.

results.title: News digest [No. 13]
results.brief_description: Cinemagazine items: Money makers produce decimal coins at Bendigo; Mt. Scurvy will disappear if quarrying continues by 1984; Tuna - a new catch in new nets off the Gippsland Lakes worth 8,000 pounds per annum; two kinds of art - Eskimos stone carvings and needlework; Erwen Ponds clear spring water attracts divers and grows huge water lilies.
